text: my father loved fishes that's why we
used to love going and fishing and
that's why we had fishes not has
tombstone
I was 23 living in California and my
sister called and she said boy there's a
guy that you just have to meet and I
said well who is he what does he do and
she said well he is a medical student
and he's Hmong and you should meet him
the first time we met that we played it
off as if we didn't know each other just
trying to keep the cool I came back home
for the Hmong new year and Chao spent
the whole day with me and my mother and
my family he also carried around my
mother's green tote and so she said
that's when she knew that he was the one
my father was diagnosed with cancer
about four years ago I remember sitting
at the footstep of my father's bed as he
took his last breath and chai was there
to hold me and to hug me
we wanted to just take a few minutes to
see my father and to pay our respects to
a man that we both love about chuckle
you know it was good to take a little
moment and just reflect on the things
that really mattered and the reason why
we got married or because of the love
and care from you know Susie's father
you loved me and you loved my family and
that meant so much to me Susie's parents
and my parents as well I think
definitely had instilled in us a love
for family and friends I think he goes
back to the history of the Hmong people
you know our culture is based on around
the family unit about loving you know
your parents your siblings your cousins
your friends because that's essentially
all they had then and I think those
values that are transferred to us I love
that you love me and you give me all
that you can and you don't just love me
but you love my family and that's what
matters
Oh
